thread.title: Georgia voters pick Ben Carson, Hillary Clinton in Peanut Poll
thread.title_full: Georgia voters pick Ben Carson, Hillary Clinton in Peanut Poll | savannahnow.com

author: Savannah Morning News
title: Georgia voters pick Ben Carson, Hillary Clinton in Peanut Poll
text:
Photos Back | Next Ben Carson Back | Next Hillary Clinton By Savannah Morning News Upon Sunday's closing of the Peanut Poll, Secretary of State Brian Kemp on Monday announced Ben Carson and Hillary Clinton as the lead vote-getters among Republicans and Democrats, respectively.
In its inaugural year at the Georgia National Fair in Perry, 28,493 straw poll voters cast peanuts for their favorite candidates. With that level of turnout, the Peanut Poll has become the largest straw poll in America, surpassing the 2015 Iowa Straw Poll by nearly 20,000 votes.
"The high levels of participation we saw in the Peanut Poll throughout the fair demonstrate a Georgia electorate that's focused on the presidential race and invested in the future of our nation," Kemp said.
"This was a fun event with a serious purpose: to inform Georgians about the SEC Primary on March 1 when our voters will have the chance to play a critical role as an early voting state to influence the presidential nominating process for both parties."
"We had fair patrons actively seeking out our booth, and voters often stood in a line out the door. Turnout and excitement like that launch new traditions, and I believe we've started a tradition in Perry."
Carson led all candidates from both parties with 8,576 votes. Clinton finished with 2,513.
In the GOP field, Donald Trump finished second with 8,099 votes. Undecided Republican voters accounted for 6.3 percent of the vote. Carly Fiorina came in fourth place with 5.2 percent, followed by Marco Rubio at 4.6 percent. Vote percentages reflect a total of 23,268 votes cast for Republicans:
— Ben Carson: 36.9%
— Donald Trump: 34.8%
— Undecided: 6.3%
— Carly Fiorina: 5.2%
— Marco Rubio: 4.6%
— Ted Cruz: 3.3 percent
— Jeb Bush: 2.7 percent
— Mike Huckabee: 2.6 percent
— Rand Paul: 1.0 percent
— John Kasich: 0.6 percent
— Chris Christie: 0.6 percent
— Rick Santorum: 0.4 percent
— Lindsey Graham: 0.3 percent
— Bobby Jindal: 0.3 percent
— George Pataki: 0.3 percent
— John Gilmore: 0.2 percent
In the Democratic contest, Clinton bested Bernie Sanders, 2,513 to 929, giving her 48.1 percent of the vote to his 17.8 percent. Based on a total of 5,225 votes cast for Democrats, vote percentages are as follows:
— Clinton: 48.1 percent
— Undecided: 22.4 percent
— Bernie Sanders: 17.8 percent
— Joe Biden: 7.6 percent
— Jim Webb: 2.1 percent
— Lincoln Chafee: 1.1 percent
— Martin O’Malley: 1.0 percent
